captions.text:
Here in the US, a disease that was all but
extinct has made a comeback.
I’m talking about measles.

It usually starts with flu-like symptoms and
a raised rash on the face, followed by inflammation

of the eyes, and then fevers as high as 40.5
degrees Celsius -- that’s 105 Fahrenheit

-- and in the very young, brain damage, hearing
loss, and even death.

The disease has been so rare in the U.S. that
it was pretty easy for scientists to figure
out where the outbreak started.

In December, a person carrying the measles
virus visited Disneyland in California.

Now, more than 100 people have been infected,
and it has spread to seventeen states.

Now, yeah, 100 people might not sound like
a lot. But keep in mind that that is twice

the number of cases the US usually sees in
an entire year, and that the outbreak is only
two months old.

Now the Centers for Disease Control is concerned
that the outbreak could gain a foothold unless
more people are vaccinated.
So how does something like this happen?
I’m Hank Green and this is SciShow News.
[Intro]

In the year 2000, scientists declared that
measles had been officially eliminated from
the United States.

Elimination, in a medical sense, means that
a disease is no longer endemic, or regularly
found in a certain region.

But eliminating the disease in the U.S. didn’t
change the fact that it was still prevalent

in other countries, like the Philippines -- where
the current strain of measles seems to be

from -- and it remains a leading cause of
death among young children worldwide. Though,

thanks to vaccinations, worldwide Measles
deaths have decreased 78% in the last ten
years.

Now, measles is a viral disease that’s communicable
through airborne droplets of water, just like

flu, and the viruses can linger on surfaces
for a couple hours.

One infected person will infect, on average,
12 to 18 other people. That’s one of the
reasons why this outbreak has spread so rapidly.

But of course, there is a vaccine for measles
-- it’s been around for 50 years.

It uses a small amount of live measles virus
that’s been weakened by a process called
cell culture adaptation.

This process basically genetically modifies
the virus by allowing it to grow inside of
some kind of medium that isn’t human cells.

In the case of the measles vaccine we do this
basically with, like, chicken embryos in a

petri dish. After a while, the virus adapts
to infecting chickens, and these adaptations
make it less virulent to humans.

While a natural measles virus reproduces thousands
of times during an infection, a weakened virus

can only reproduce about twenty times inside
of a human host.

But that’s just enough so that it doesn't
cause any symptoms, but it does stimulate

an immune response in our bodies, which allows
us to produce antibodies.

Throughout the rest of our lives, those antibodies
will be able to identify a measles virus so

that our immune system can be awesome at destroying
it.

But … the system isn’t quite perfect.
3 to 5 percent of the population can still
contract measles even if they’re vaccinated.

And yet, if a high enough percentage of the
population is immunized, the virus can’t
spread.

Instead of each infected person creating twelve
or eighteen new disease vectors, the average

person creates less than one new disease vector,
and thus, the outbreak just doesn't happen.

This, my fellow herd-members, is called herd
immunity.

And it means that an entire community can/be
protected, even if a few of those members
aren’t immune to the pathogen.

In the case of the measles, 92 to 94 percent
of a population has to be immunized in order
for herd immunity to protect the whole group.
So, how do we know all this?

Well, a widespread vaccination program for
measles, mumps and rubella -- all airborne
viral diseases -- began in the US in 1963.

And as the country’s herd immunity increased,
the incidence of measles went from 3 to 4

million cases a year in the 1950s down to
just 37 cases in 2004.

But in recent years, immunization rates have
began declining, due in part to the growing

misconceptions that have erroneously linked
these vaccines to autism and other disorders.

As a result, in nearly 500 public schools
at ground zero for the current outbreak -- in

Southern California -- the immunization rate
has fallen below that 92 percent threshold,

which has given the measles an opportunity
to spread again.

But people who’ve contracted measles from
this latest outbreak are all over the country
-- more than half of them weren’t vaccinated.

Immunization rates in eight other states are
even lower than California’s -- with Colorado

coming in last, at around 81 percent. So this
is probably not the last we’ve heard from
measles.
Our herd is being compromised.
But, how did we get here?

How did we get to the point where people stopped
using safe and effective protection against

a disease, and decide instead to take their
chances?

We’ll be talking about the science of why
we sometimes ignore science, in a special
infusion next week, so be sure to join us.

In the meantime, thanks for watching SciShow
News. If you want to help us share science

with the world, you can become a supporting
subscriber at Subbable.com/scishow. And if

you want to keep getting smarter with us,
you can go to youtube.com/scishow and subscribe.

comments.text:
http://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/vsus/vsrates1940_60.pdf

Yawn. This is getting old. 

People try to point the finger at one specific group, you're just grasping 
for straws. 

First of all, immigration is undoubtedly an indicator of wild-strain 
diseases being brought across the borders. Since I was a child, it has more 
than doubled. 

Secondly, the trend from the early 20th century till the first 
single-strain vaccine was introduced was showing a decline. People 
attempting to form a correlation between vaccines and a decline that 
happened literally decades prior to its introduction are pretty desperate 
in their attempt to defend vaccines. 

Yet oddly enough, we have stuff like this 
http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/189/Supplement_1/S17.full.pdf  

"Measles case fatality decreased from 21 deaths/1000 reported
cases in 1911–1912 to !1 death/1000 in 1953–
1962. This improvement in survival of people infected
with measles virus presumably resulted from improved
nutrition and medical care, especially the availability of
newly discovered antibiotics to treat many of the bacterial
complications of measles."

Same can be applicable to many other ailments that can quite honestly be 
handled with even the most minimal of additional nutrient supplementation. 

If you want to trust the most money-hungry industry on the planet, by all 
means, vaccinate your child and hope they won't end up as one of the 
unlucky ones experiencing serious adverse reactions. I look at vaccines as 
any other pharmaceutical. Are people dropping dead left and right from 
taking such-and-such drug? No. Should it be mandatory that I take 
such-and-such drug for blankety-blank? No. 

There are alternatives out to defend, and help you recover from disease. 
You don't need to inject yourselves with synthetics that carry the 
potential to harm rather than "do good." 

If you'd like to argue the effectiveness of alternative treatments versus 
that of the modern medical industry, by all means, I have quite literally 
thousands of testimonials to draw from and plenty of MD's and a few 
biochemists/pharmacists that would tend to disagree with your stance. ﻿

comments.author: C Steele

comments.text:
It depends how good and healthy your immune system is.
The immune cells travel through water, that's another reason to drink water 
and eating healthy foods depending on the environment your living in will 
help a lot.

If your immune system is good and healthy, then when most of your lymph 
nodes are 'destroyed', the remaining Dendritic Cells can survive long 
enough to reach to the closest lymph node to activate loads of B Cells and 
T Cells.

If your immune system isn't strong enough, then there will be no access to 
any lymph nodes and the measles would start damaging organs rapidly. Then 
the cytokine storm starts:

A cytokine is a protein that marks a particular spot, there are many of 
them but when a cytokine storm is released, every cytokine is released 
causing the body to shoot at everything (immune cells, body cells, any 
cells).
A cytokine storm will NOT be effective if the immune system is weak and 
that'll just be a perfect tool to kill yourself.
A cytokine storm will be good if the immune system is good, however, the 
feeling will be much worse and it will cause more damage, a bit of a 
paradox eh'?

If the cytokine storm is successful then the body starts producing a lot of 
antibodies around the openings of the body so that you will be immune for 
at least 10 years.
If your immune system is good and healthy, your immune system will remember 
it forever.

So drink water and eat healthy or there will be consequences.﻿

comments.author: Andrew Shannon

comments.text:
"...virus weakened enough not to give symptoms, but to stimulate an immune 
response." Wouldn't you like to know if your immune system is capable of 
mounting such a response *before* the vaccine? How about your child's 
immune system? How about your infant's? See, much of the damage being 
allegedly caused by vaccines could be further ruled out by having a simple 
blood test prior to the initiation of vaccination. But they'd rather not do 
that -- they'd rather not take into account the well-known growing immune 
and auto-immune disorders (which, like autism spectrum, aren't understood 
by medicine). Why? Isn't medicine supposed to err on the side of caution 
and preservation of health. If a test is available (and it is), why 
shouldn't that be done to determine the appropriate schedule and 
administration of a lifetime of important vaccinations and other 
medications? Also, herd immunity through vaccination is largely mythical -- 
based on the reality of the timeframe he used in discussing the disease's 
eradication. So, we got here (as he asked) by medical science believing the 
variables involved in a healthy cross section of the population are 
unchanged in the last 50 years. But that rise in immune and auto-immune 
conditions happened in that time period (among other new conditions), and 
there's little medical understanding of them. The discussion becomes the 
big misunderstanding at this same point in every case -- at the end of the 
video, it's condescend condescend condescend... we who trust science (that 
admittedly doesn't know the variables in ASD as one example) are so above 
you... condescend condescend. It's sophisticated -- and therefore, 
convincing -- ignorance, not science.﻿

comments.text:
I can shoot down your Herd theory with a case at a school in Quebec.  Out 
of 94 vaccinated students, over 50% of the students caught measles.  The 
given efficacy and efficiency they claim is 85% to 95% from one single dose 
of MMR.  So this is a false claim.  You can't predict the efficacy or 
efficiency of a vaccine from one person to another. Its been noted on 
testing the individuals with low immunity needed 4 shots just to get to the 
claimed level.  So the spread factor is being lied about.﻿

comments.author: Keira Churchill

comments.text:
+TheBookWorm1718 Well, Vitamin A is important.  Vaccination is important 
too.  I'd say take care of both.  You don't want to be messing about with 
Hypervitaminosis A risks after the event when a simple vaccination should 
do the trick.

With your case of a vaccinated person getting measeles and passing it on to 
other vaccinated people, it's more likely that the people lost immunity due 
to age than the vaccination simply not working.  A booster shot may have 
been in order.  I don't know the case, not the age of the people involved, 
so I can't really comment.
comments.author: Keira Churchill

comments.text:
+Keira Churchill  Thing is once you actually have it, you never have to 
worry about it again, and statistics say in the last 10 years there've been 
1000 cases of it in the US and not one death directly tied to them. Now in 
other countries, yes, but this is America and we may have a couple hundred 
cases of measles a year, but nobody's making the news for croaking from 
them.

As for serious cases, the Mayo Clinic says you're more likely to get 
measles at all, AND for it to be severe, if you don't have enough vitamin A 
in your system, that's certainly something WELL within people's control, 
but likely they ignore it because it's not convenient, it would be an 
almost daily task to actually eat healthy and cook real food instead of 
just what's quick and individually wrapped and tastes like grease and 
sugar. And as for supplements, the Mayo Clinic doesn't put much faith in 
them, because their efficiency is still being questioned. People with 
severe cases of measles have to receive 100,000 IU of vitamin A over a 
course of 2 days, which would be the equivalent of 20 of those supplements. 
It seems to me it'd be easier to just start reading labels to know what has 
it, and eating more of it, which really is something everybody should be 
doing anyway, less Burger King and more spinach and carrots and yams and 
tomatoes and eggs and milk and apricots and mangoes aren't going to hurt 
people. What measles does is deplete the vitamin A, which is what keeps the 
immune system strong, so maybe people ought to lay off McDonald's a few 
nights a week and actually cook real meals with vegetables in them, whether 
their kids like it or not.
comments.author: TheBookWorm1718

comments.text:
Vaccination is the best we can do.  Viruses mutate and evolve like any 
organism and there can be several strains doing the rounds.  If someone is 
vaccinated then they are far less likely to be affected by the virus than 
if they were not.

Vaccination won't save everyone all of the time, but the alternative is 
hardly anyone escaping the associated disease.  I know which option I 
prefer.
comments.author: Keira Churchill
